content:
Nice clash.

One current issue with it is that [[N]] is not a prime for 13/14 tests+validators, the only time [[N]] is prime is Test "Not Found" where it is 5. This means that in Shortest mode, you can simply treat [[N]] as part of the list of integers and since none of the validators have a prime [[N]] then it will never affect the result in those. So if you're sneaky, you can save a few characters this way.
It's not a big deal, but it's one of the reasons why its good to have tests and validators be the same size as each other.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty easy to understand and fast to solve. Good job!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good puzzle, took a second to figure out a solution but definetly doable in the time given for a clash of code

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's simple, there's a good solution(now), and it's also pretty unique. Good Job!
Maybe find a better way for the solution, hardcoding is not the way to go. XD

Cool puzzle, quite simple, but your solution with hardcoded primes from 2 to 997 sucks lol.
Clearly too hard for reverse mode in my opinion.
Great for shortest and fastest, especially shortest where you have to figure out how to test if a number is prime the shortest way.

I see reverse mode as viable due to the "NO PRIMES" test cases, which players will get to see as well. That more or less gives the puzzle away.

I am also too lazy to implement the Sieve of Eratosthenes lol. Maybe it might be the most optimal solution for the shortest game mode, but hardcoded wins every time in fastest mode :)
I have edited my solution, thank you.
That's an interesting consideration, I think it'll work well for the shortest game mode if someone figures that out.

Ah yes with the NO PRIMES it's possible in reverse.
How do you come up with all those hardcoded primes in a correct python syntax so fast lol?
Not even the sieve of eratosthenes, but simply a loop that basically tests if the number is divisible by something between 2 and the number - 1. That's possible because of your constraint 1<=num<=1000, but if the numbers get bigger, this will take too much time to compute.
;)
I just copied the list from https://prime-numbers.info/list/primes#google_vignette and added some formatting. Your suggestion also makes sense; didn't think of that.

Yeah obviously you copied pasted them from somewhere. Not a fan of that, seems like cheating if you have to go to another website and copy data, you might as well just go on chatgpt.com for the list and the whole solution. I'm extrapolating but you know what I mean.
Anyway fun challenge ;)
